awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Academic Success and Professional Development (ASAP) Project-Based Engineering Excellence Transfer Academy Across Arizona
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project is a collaborative effort between Arizona State University, Central Arizona College, Cochise College, Eastern Arizona College, Estrella Mountain Community College, Glendale Community College, Mesa Community College, Mohave Community College, Phoenix College, and Yavapai College. The program will provide scholarships for talented, low-income students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing degrees in engineering or computer science. In addition to scholarships, the program will provide academic and other support to increase the persistence of these academically talented, low-income students.  The project design includes an academic success and professional development course along with project-based activities.  Faculty and industrial mentors help students to envision the potential career opportunities and benefits available in engineering and computer science. Nine of the ten collaborating schools are classified as Hispanic Serving Institutions. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain engineering or computer science degrees will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well being of the nation.

The project seeks to address the need to expand the engineering and computer science workforce by increasing the success of Arizona State University students including students that transfer from community colleges. The program combines a network of engineering mentors with a successful student-centered and mentor-driven academic success and professional development course to significantly increase the number of community college students that consider, choose, continue and graduate with a bachelor of science in engineering or computer science.  At the center of the proposed initiative is a commitment to involving students in career-shaping projects that will permit them to discover, nurture, and fully develop their technical interests. Guided by grounded theory and social cognitive career theory, the project will also study the factors most central to maintaining effectiveness while scaling up a successful student-centered and mentor-intensive transfer student support system to encompass a larger group of collaborating institutions. Community colleges will play an increasingly important role in educating the nation's engineers. This statewide project will serve as a collaborative model for four-year and two-year schools across the nation. This research will provide knowledge helpful in establishing a transfer student support program in Arizona and will inform other university and community college networks in other parts of the United States. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the engineering and computer science education community.

por.por_cntn:
In February 2016, Glendale Community College (GCC) applied for a five-year S-STEMS grant as part of a multi-institution program, which was titled "Collaborative Research: Academic Success and Professional Development (ASAP) Project-Based Engineering Excellence Transfer Academy Across Arizona". GCC was subsequently awarded the grant, which had a start date of September 1, 2016. GCC’s share of the grant award was $125,000. The purpose of this grant was to provide scholarships and career development opportunities for engineering or computer science students at GCC, a Hispanic Serving Institute (HSI). The student activities were designed to help students take control of their education and maximize their careers opportunities. Most engineering and computer science students at GCC typically transfer to one of the in-state universities (primarily Arizona State University, which is approximately 25 miles from GCC) to complete their bachelor’s and often their master’s degrees.

 

The specific goals for the ASAP program at GCC were to:  (1) provide scholarship money to students pursuing degrees in engineering or computers science; (2) mentor students to help them remain successful in their courses and future careers; (3) guide students through the transfer process into a university to earn a BS degree in engineering or computer science; and (4) help students create resumes, career plans, and interest papers to prepare them for their future careers in engineering or computer science.

 

Because the date of the initial award was well after the start of 2016-2017 academic year, no scholarships were awarded during that first academic year, which was used for planning purposes. The first scholarships were awarded in August 2017; consequently, GCC still had unspent scholarship money when the program was originally scheduled to end in September 2021. Hence, GCC requested and received a 1-year no-cost extension, with the last of the scholarships being awarded during the spring semester of 2022.

 

Over the entire grant period, GCC awarded a total of $99,150, (79.3% of our budget), to 50 students in the form of scholarships, with the remaining money used for personnel expenses, travel, and indirect costs. (The proposed budget had only $75,000 applied towards scholarships, so GCC was able to minimize operating costs and provide more money for student scholarships.)  Of these 50 students, 31 (62%) of them were from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM (women, Hispanics, African Americans, and Native Americans). The minimum eligibility requirements for students to receive a scholarship were:

  • US Citizen or permanent resident.
  • Full-time student (12+ credit hours) at GCC, taking courses toward an AS or AAS degree with the intent of transferring to a university to complete a baccalaureate degree.
  • Majoring in Engineering or Computer Science and currently enrolled in at least one engineering or computer science course, (courses with an ECE, EEE, or CSC prefix).
  • Successfully completed at least 12 college credits (100- or 200- level courses) with a GPA of 3.2 or higher.
  • Successfully completed ECE102: Engineering Analysis Tools and Techniques with a grade of B or higher. (ECE102 is required for both engineering and computer science majors.)
  • Currently enrolled in MAT220: Calculus I or a higher-level math class. (Students do not need to be enrolled in a math course if all of their math requirements have already been met.)
  • Financial need. This is determined through the GCC Financial Aid Office by completing the Free Application for Federal Financial Aid (FAFSA) form.
  • Annual Family Income below $65,000.

 

A committee of 3-4 engineering faculty would meet during the week before the start of the semester and evaluate (rank) the applications from students that met the eligibility requirements. (These engineering faculty also served as faculty mentors to the students selected for the ASAP program.)  Some semesters, there were more scholarships available than applications that met the minimum requirements. In those cases, all of the eligible students were admitted into the program and the application deadline was usually extended in the hopes of receiving more applications.

 

In fall of 2022, follow-up surveys were sent to the former ASAP program participants. Of those 50 students, 3 at still taking classes at GCC, 15 are taking classes at ASU, and 2 are taking classes at other universities, (University of Southern California & Northern Arizona University). All 20 of these students indicated that they are still majoring in engineering or computer science. Another 17 participants already graduated from ASU with a BS in engineering or computer science and are working in a STEM field. Two participants did not graduate from a university but are working in a STEM field, (engineering technician, nuclear operator in Navy). Two were working in non-STEM careers, and the whereabouts of the remaining 9 former participants is unknown. Thus, at least 39 (78%) of the program participants are either working in a STEM field or pursuing a degree in one. 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2023
Modified by: Tim S Frank
